QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the role of counselling doctors attached to his Department.
(2) By what means may a doctor ascertain the correct Medical Benefits Schedule Item to charge for each procedure.
(3) Did his Department allow overpayment from June 1981 to February 1982 to Dr B. Wainer in relation to disputed claims relating to Item 797; if so, why.
(4) What guidelines govern the relationship between the Minister for Health, doctors with his Department and private medical practitioners.
(5) If patient histories are to be seized, is it the practice for this to be done by police officers or by medical practitioners; if not the latter, why not.
(6) Why was the warrant to search Dr Wainer's clinic and home on 19 February 1982 sought in such wide terms.
(7) Were there documents seized in the raid that were not related to Dr Wainer' s medical practice; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The role of a counsellor is to counsel, to advise, to discuss, to clarify and interpret the Medical Benefits Scheme and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme . In specific circumstances, a warning may be given regarding possible future reference to a Committee of Inquiry.

(2) By reference to the Medical Benefits Schedule Book. This Book is provided to doctors as the primary means for ascertaining the correct item for a medical service. Each item has a description of the medical service to which it applies.

It also contains explanatory notes for interpretation of the schedule, and on the Medical Benefits Scheme generally. If a doctor is uncertain about the particular item number which applies to a medical service, he should contact the Commonwealth Director of Health in his State.

(3) During that period, benefits were paid in accordance with claims lodged. My Department is reluctant to disadvantage doctors or their patients during a period when the Department is identifying and quantifying any possible breaches of the medical benefits legislation.

(4) The relationship between the Minister and doctors within his Department is the normal Minister-public servant relationship governed by the Public Service Act and Regulations, and the General Orders relating thereto, and amplified in the Official conduct Guidelines for Commonwealth Public Servants issued by the Public Service Board.

The relationship between doctors within the Department and private medical practitioners is governed by those sections of the guidelines referred to above which have regard to the relationship between officers and members of the public , coupled with the relevant sections of the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act, and other legislation pertaining to the activities of the Department. There are also specific guidelines on action to be taken by a Departmental medical counsellor who becomes aware of a possible breach of the law during a counselling interview, set out in a procedural directive circulated to State Offices of the Department on 9 June 1982.

(5) It is a responsibility of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to investigate alleged offences against Commonwealth law. The gathering of evidence is part of that role. In each case where a search warrant is sought, the police must satisfy a Stipendiary Magistrate by evidence on oath that sufficient grounds exist to justify the issue of the warrant. In executing the warrant, and in the conduct of the subsequent investigation, procedures have been devised by the AFP in consultation with the Australian Medical Association and my Department to protect the privacy and confidentiality of the patient's medical history, and to prevent unauthorised access to records under police control.

(6) I am advised that the scope of the warrant was appropriate to the suspected offences and complied with guidelines set down by recent decisions of the Victorian Supreme Court. The terms of the warrant were drafted on the advice of the Office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor, Melbourne.
(7) I am advised that only documents relating to Dr Wainer's medical practice were seized.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to President Carter's report on restructuring the United Nnations system submitted to the United States Congress in the 1978 fiscal year (Public Law 95-105).

(2) If so, is he able to say whether the President called for (a) strengthening the UN, (b) a UN Charter Review Conference, if a substantial majority of member states believe it likely to be productive, (c) review and promotion of peaceful dispute settlement measures, (d) yearly Foreign Minister meetings on peace, (e) the International Court of Justice to give advisory opinions to national appellate courts on international laws, (f) wider compulsory jurisdiction for the ICJ, (g) national contingents trained in peace-keeping as a UN reserve force , supported by national airlift facilities and a fund of the order of then $ US100m, (h) UN associate membership for very small states, (j) independent revenue sources for the international community and (k) UN agencies to be the major channels for international technical aid.
(3) To which of these principles does the Australian Government subscribe as they apply to Australia.
(4) What has been done to implement each of those principles Australia has accepted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (k) This is not a wholly accurate rendition of what was contained in the earlier report. The report called for a strengthening of the role of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) as the major channel for voluntary contributions for the technical assistance programs of the UN system.

(3) and (4) The Foreign Affairs Committee of the United States House of Representatives held hearings on this report, but there was no specific follow- up in the United Nations. The recommendations of the report appear to have been left simply for the record, implicitly to be pursued only if and when the climate becomes favourable.

Australia is in broad sympathy with a number of the principles enunciated in the report and spoke accordingly under relevant individual agenda items in the Sixth (legal) Committee of the UN General Assembly. It is to be regretted that to date a broad international consensus on reform and restructure of the UN system is lacking, but, as the report notes, until such a consensus develops, it is unlikely that any of those principles will be implemented.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Questions on Use of Toxic Chemicals in Vietnam: Department of Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) questions without notice, and (b) questions on notice, has he, or his predecessors, received since 1 January 1978 on any matters related to or arising out of United States, Australian, and allied forces use of toxic chemicals in Vietnam during hostilities here.
(2) Who was the member or senator asking the question, and what is the full Hansard reference, in each case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether A. L. Maduska and others (Am. J. Obstet, Gynecol. , 130, 84, 1980) have evidence that maternal fluoride levels are occasionally above 50 micromol/L with the usual exposure to methoxyflurane and with high fetal to maternal flouride ratio.
(2) Do adults vary in susceptibility to high-output renal failure with high blood fluoride.
(3) Have studies been done to suggest renal damage in the newborn from exogenous flouride.

(4) Is he able to say whether the decision to ban flouride supplements in pregnancy in New York was due solely to a belief that these supplements were ineffective; if so, what other examples of such bans of medication solely on the grounds of ineffectiveness are known; if not, on what evidence were the other grounds for the ban based.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In their study on pregnant ewes (Am. J. Obstet. Gynecol. 136, 84, 1980), Maduska and others did report serum inorganic fluoride levels above 50 micromol per litre, compared to a mean maternal baseline of 13.3 micromol. This rise in serum level followed the administration intravenously of a large quantity of sodium fluoride-20 ml of a solution of 100 parts per million were rapidly introduced. In the study, the ewes were not exposed to methoxyflurane. The anaesthetic administered was halothane, a stable fluroine compound. The study was designed to measure the effect of sodium fluoride-not fluoride released from methoxyflurane-on maternal and fetal serum flouride levels.

(2) Yes. The presence of existing kidney disease and its degree of severity, obesity and the PH of the urine are among the factors influencing individual susceptibility to this classification of renal failure.
(3) No studies have been reported in the scientific literature concerning renal damage in the newborn from exogenous fluoride.

(4) The 'ban' imposed by the United States Food and Drug Administration in 1966 in New York and other States was a 'ban' on the advertising and promotion of sodium fluoride supplements in respect of claims for efficacy. It was not a 'ban ' on the use of these supplements. In the United States, 'bans' on advertisements, which claimed an effect not proven, have been imposed for many years. The 'bans' apply to many other readily available substances, including other dietary supplements, analgesics and mouth-rinses.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hamlin Medical Trust Fund of Ethiopia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: Will financial aid be given to the Hamlin Medical Trust Fund of Ethiopia to assist Australian gynaecologists continue to help Ethiopian women with internal injuries received during difficult and unsuccessful births.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Financial assistance is provided for organisations such as the Hamlin Medical Trust Fund of Ethiopia only through Australian non-government organisations ( NGOs) which have been approved for this purpose. Such assistance has been provided previously to the Hamlin Medical Trust Fund of Ethiopia, and notice of its work will be brought to the attention of approved Australian NGOs for their consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a computer letter sent to all pensioners who are no longer entitled to retain their health benefit card or concession card.

(2) Does the letter advise pensioners to check with the State health authority to see if they can still receive free hospital services; if so, as Queensland has a free hospital system, should this part of the letter be censored for Queensland pensioners as it may cause them alarm.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A letter is automatically produced by computer and forwarded to pensioners who are no longer entitled to retain their health benefit card or concession card requesting the cards be returned.
(2) Yes. The text of the letter does advise the pensioner to check with the State Health Authority.

It is considered desirable for the pensioner to do so, so that he is fully aware of the situation applicable to him. The arrangements for the provision of full medical and hospital care to holders of Commonwealth health benefits cards are different from the arrangements existing in State hospitals, particularly where the pensioner has been receiving treatment by a private medical practitioner.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Answering of Questions on Notice: Minister for Aviation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the Minister's arrangements for the answering of questions on notice, specifying what officers (a) on the Minister's personal staff and (b) within the Minister's Department, are responsible for (i) examining the question asked and (ii) preparing the answers.
(2) How many questions on notice, from senators and members, has the Minister been asked from 25 November 1980 to date.
(3) What is the average delay incurred between the time of questions being placed on notice and the provision of the answer.
(4) For each question referred to in part (2), how many have taken (a) 1-3 months, (b) 3-6 months, (c) 6-9 months, (d) 9-12 months and (e) over 12 months, to be answered.
(5) How many of these questions are currently still on notice, and what is the reason for delay in the case of each question which has been on the Notice Paper of either House for 12 months or more.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is a follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Notice Papers are examined every sitting day both by my Senior Private Secretary and by the Director, Ministerial and Parliamentary Liaison Section of my Department. Answers are prepared in the relevant Division of my Department and submitted by the Division Head for my approval.

(2) On the date of my appointment as Minister for Aviation, 7 May 1982, there were 48 outstanding questions on notice to the Minister for Transport which became by responsibility. From that date up to 23 September 1982 I have been asked 40 questions.

(3) For the outstanding questions on notice on the date of my appointment as the Minister for Aviation, the average delay was 11 weeks. For questions asked since 7 May 1982, the average delay has been 5 weeks.
(5) There were 29 questions on notice on 23 September 1982. None were more than 12 months old.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Non-aligned Movement Summit Meeting: Australian Observers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Having regard to Australia's increasing involvement in the Middle East, and the size of the membership of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM), what consideration did the Government give to sending a (a) Government and (b) Parliamentary, representative to the 7th NAM summit meeting to be held in Baghdad, 6-10 September 1982.
(2) Will any official Australian observers be present; if so (a) who are they, (b) what is their status and (c) to whom will they report.
(3) If no Australian observers will be present; why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government gave no consideration to sending a Government representative to the 7th Non-Aligned Conference of Heads of State. The question of attendance by a representative of the Parliament would of course be a matter for Parliament itself. In any event, the meeting has been postponed and is likely to be transferred to another venue.

(2) and (3) Australia is not a member of the Non-Aligned Movement. It is not the normal practice of the Non-Aligned Movement to extend invitations to aligned countries to attend NAM meetings, whether as Observers or Guests.

(8) There are two components to the statistical reporting system at the national level:

(a) Workload Statistics-The workload statistics provide information on the operations of the centres by measuring the major activities conducted by the staff. This includes identifying the type of counselling (i.e., counselling new clients, telephone counselling, casual contacts) and other non-client related activities (e.g. staff development) conducted in the centres. The indicators in this system are the number of contacts and time spent on each activity.

(b) Client-Specific Data Base-This data base provides basic statistical information about the clients, the problems they are experiencing, patterns of utilisation of the centres and counselling outcomes.
As the veteran is considered to be the prime client and the system is veteran oriented, data collected on this system pertain to veterans.
(i) Veterans' details-including sex, marital status, number of children and Repatriation details;
(ii) service details-including the Branch of Service and details of tours of duty in Vietnam;
(iii) contact details-including with whom the contact was made (i.e., veteran, spouse) and the problems involved;
(iv) type of counselling-individual, group or family; and
(v) referral information-including the agency to which referred (i.e., Local Government, non-Government, voluntary) and the reason for referral (e.g., legal, drug/alcohol, employment).
(9) Statistics on the V.V.C.S., as on most other operations, are collected on a four-weekly cost period basis. This enables consistent comparisons to be made between different periods.
Statistics are also collected in terms of client contacts and tables giving these are set out below. Definitions of the terms used in these tables are as follows:

Client: for unique identification purposes the prime client is the veteran, although contacts may be with veteran and spouse/others. References to 'client' refer to the veteran or any family or other associate.
New Client Contact: the first contact at the Centre by a client, after which contact the client is registered (i.e. at the time of contact no registered client file number is held at the Centre).
Past Client Contact: a second or subsequent contact at the Centre by a registered client (i.e. a client file is held at the Centre).
Casual Client Contact: (i) an initial contact by a client after which contact the client is not registered. This could include contacts made on country visits .

(ii) a contact by a client, either registered or unregistered, which is not part of a specific counselling plan (i.e. in the case of a registered client a contact which is not part of a Counsellor's course of treatment and no record is made of the contact on the file) e.g. attendance at a self-help group.
Outside Contact: a contact with a registered client outside the Centre, e.g. home visit, hospital visit.
If a contact is made outside the Centre with an unregistered client this is included as a casual client contact.

Telephone Contact: a contact by telephone with either a registered or unregistered client. Telephone contacts are included only if they involve the provision of a professional service by the Counsellor. Appointment making and discussions about clients are not included. In the case of a registered client the client's file may or may not be noted.
The number of clients registered with each Centre for each period is given by the figure in the column ''New Clients''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the eligibility criteria the Minister is using to define 'a severely handicapped person' as qualification for the new Mobility Allowance.
(2) Why is the implementation of the scheme being delayed until April 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The detailed conditions of eligibility for the new Mobility Allowance are currently under consideration by my department. When these are finalised I will make a further statement on the matter.

(2) Considerable work is involved in setting up the Mobility Allowance assessment and payment mechanisms and procedures. It is anticipated that April 1983 will be the earliest practical target date for implementing the scheme.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government made provision in 1982-83 for funding an Attendant Care Scheme for disabled persons to enable them to live in private accommodation of their choice, if so:
(a) what is the amount of the grant,
(b) how will the grant be administered,
(c) when will the scheme be implemented,
(d) how many disabled people will be assisted by the scheme, and
(e) have intended recipients been consulted regarding the operation of the scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Provision has been made in 1982-83, for the conduct of a pilot attendant care scheme designed to examine the feasibility of alternative modes of providing attendant care assistance.
(a) A total of $100,000 has been provided to conduct the pilot during 1982-83.
(b) These funds will be administered through the Department of Social Security.
(c) The pilot is expected to commence in March 1983.
(d) My department is currently developing proposals for the conduct of the pilot for my consideration. The number of disabled persons to be included in the pilot will be considered in this context.
(e) Potential participants in the pilot have not yet been identified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to give estimates of the total explosive power used in (a) military action in Indo-China in the period of involvement of United States of America and Australian Forces, (b) World War I and (c) World War II.

(2) Is he able to say what is the estimated explosive power now stockpiled by the permanent members of the (a) United Nations Security Council, (b) Northern Atlantic Treaty Organisation and (c) Warsaw Pact.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is not possible to estimate with any degree of certainty the explosive power used in the conflicts listed in the first part of the question; nor is it possible to estimate the explosive power of stockpiles of conventional and nuclear weapons at present held by the countries mentioned. A report on nuclear weapons, which was submitted by the Secretary-General of the United Nations to the Thirty-fifth Session of the United Nations General Assembly on 12 September 1980 (UN Document A/35/392), noted that while the exact number of nuclear warheads in the world at that time was unknown, the total was estimated to be in excess of 40,000, with a strength probably equivalent of some 13,000 million tons of TNT.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the allegation by Dr R. Watson, Director, Chemical Defence Experimental Establishment, Porton Down, United Kingdom, that Australia's main contribution to the 1965 Technical Co-operation Program agreement was for the testing of equipment developed in Britain and the United States of America, as reported in the book A Higher Form of Killing, R. Harris and J. Paxman, published by Chatto and Windus, 1982, page 175.
(2) Can he confirm or deny this allegation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, but I am uncertain whether these are Dr Watson's words or interpretations made by the authors of the book concerned, based upon their interview with him. The Technical Co-operation Program comprehends exchanges of results of research and development in many subjects in defence science and in maintaining the knowledge of the state-of-art.

The Government would be negligent if it did not take the necessary steps to develop its defences against the threat posed by chemical agents; accordingly exchanges and cross-testing of protective clothing and detection equipment have taken place between Australia and other countries. However I am advised no large -scale field testing of chemical warfare equipment or agents has taken place in Australia since World War II.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What have been Australia's wheat sales to the USSR in each year since 1977.
(2) Is there a potential for sale of canned fruit to the USSR; if so, why has this sale not proceeded.
(3) If it is government policy which has caused this sale not to proceed, is the Government intending to compensate the canned fruit industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Shipments of Australian wheat in each year since 1976-77 under sales negotiated with USSR are as follows:

(2) Australia has never exported canned fruit to the USSR and all information gathered by Government sources strongly suggests that future sales prospects are very limited. The value of canned and bottled fruit imports by the USSR has ranged from around $3.1 m to $4.7 m per annum over the period 1976 to 1981, and virtually all these imports have come from Bulgaria and Hungary who would have the capacity to substantially expand sales to the USSR if the demand arose in future. Moreover, the USSR's current situation of 'hard' currency shortage would be likely to preclude at this stage the possibility of the USSR seeking to augment supplies from traditional Socialist country sources with purchases from developed Western countries.
(3) The Government's policy towards the USSR provides no impediment to the sale of canned fruit on normal commercial terms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the 1976 report on environmental considerations of visits of nuclear powered warships to Australia which recommends the establishment of a Naval Nuclear Ship Safety Organisation in each port to be visited by nuclear powered warships.
(2) Have these organisations been established; if so (a) in which ports and (b) in what years were they established.
(3) What steps were taken by the Commonwealth to ensure that such organisations were established.

(4) Do these organisations conform in detail to the structure and functioning laid out in annex C, paragraphs 43-58, and appendix 2 of the annex of the report ; if not, where and in what ways do they vary from the guidelines.
(5) What assistance has been sought by, and offered to, State governments in establishing these organisations and from which Commonwealth Departments and for what purposes has this assistance come.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. Port safety organisations were set up in Melbourne, Hobart and Fremantle in 1976, Darwin in 1978 and Brisbane in 1982.
(3) Consultations took place between Commonwealth and State officials and the organisations were set up with the full co-operation of the State Governments concerned.

(5) Assistance has mainly consisted of the provision of technical advice, manpower for radiation monitoring programs, and radiation monitoring equipment. In addition the Commonwealth has carried out analysis of environmental samples as part of the routine environmental monitoring program. Commonwealth authorities involved have been Defence, Home Affairs and Environment, Health and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When were the operating theatres at Concord Repatriation Hospital last refurbished and renovated.
(2) What action is taken to minimise the risk of contamination and cross infection due to lack of separate 'clean' and 'dirty' traffic ways in and out of each theatre.
(3) When will the theatres be modernised and refurbished.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, has seven operating theatres located in two separate areas of the hospital. Three theatres are located on the seventh floor of the multi-storey building and were constructed in the 1940s. Four theatres are located in the administration building and were built in 1971.

A continuing repairs and maintenance program is undertaken in both areas to ensure the standards appropriate for modern surgical procedures are maintained. The maintenance of sterile conditions is emphasised and a regular replacement program for air-conditioning filters and waste lines leading from the theatres is undertaken. Examples of recent major repairs and maintenance work on the operating theatres include-
1977-78-$15,000 to repair ceiling and walls of the theatre in the administrative building.
1979-80-$16,000 to repair and replace floor coverings in the theatres in the multi-storey building.
1982-83-$35,000 to paint and carry out minor repairs in the theatres in the administrative building.

(2) In the administrative building theatres 'dirty' or used instruments are enclosed on trolleys in protective coverings at the end of each surgical procedure and disposed of by way of a life/'dumb waiter' connected to the dirty area of the Theatre Sterilising unit. This disposal procedure ensures that dirty material leaves the operating theatres by a route separate from that taken by the patient. All 'dirty' linen is sealed in protective bags prior to leaving the operating room. Disposal of used materials in this manner minimises the risk of cross infection.

In the other theatres, all used equipment and instrumentation are cleaned in a wash steriliser unit before leaving the clean-up area located between the operating rooms. After cleaning, instruments are transferred to the central sterile unit for re-sterilisation.

Regular microbiological tests of the air, water and equipment are conducted in both operating suites, the results of which are monitored by the hospital's infection control committee. The hospital has not experienced any significant instances of cross-infection or contamination in either operating suite.

(3) Plans to upgrade and relocate the operating theatre services at the hospital are presently under review by the Department of Veterans' Affairs with a view to bringing forward a proposal for Government consideration.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Reorganisation of Central Office

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1982:

(2) When was the review commenced which led to this reorganisation.
(3) Who were the (a) Departmental and (b) other Public Service officers who carried out the review.
(4) Who initiated the review, and when.
(5) Who was responsible for submitting the review report and its recommendations to the Public Service Board.
(6) What problems and deficiencies were identified by the review.
(7) Will the Minister present the review report to Parliament; if not, why not.
(8) How many officers at (a) the central office and (b) regional offices, will be attached to the Benefits and Special Projects Division which has been approved by the Public Service Board.
(9) What is the designation, classification and salary of each of those officers.
(10) How many of those officers will be personnel who are currently employed in the Vietnam Special Studies Group.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (10) The top structure of the Department's Central Office had remained basically unchanged since 1964. The main purpose of the review was to examine the current and future roles of the Divisions, analyse any problems and deficiencies with the structure and provide a more efficient, upgraded organisation, better suited to our needs.
The review was initiated by the Permanent Head in November 1981 and preliminary work, fact finding, et cetera, commenced from that time.
The Permanent Head submitted the final report to the Public Service Board.

The review was conducted as an internal, departmental organisation review and was submitted for the Public Service Board to handle under section 29 of the Public Service Act. This is consistent with the approach adopted in such reviews . Information about the re-organisation was provided to Senate Estimates Committee 'G' on 16 September 1982.

So far only the top structure (Second Division) part of the Benefits and Special Projects Division has been approved by the Public Service Board. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are nuclear exclusion clauses contained in property and liability insurance policies such that, in the event of any accident with nuclear materials involving damage or contamination, insured property owners would be unable to claim compensation.
(2) If so, what is the attitude of the Commonwealth in the case of such eventualities with regard to the acceptance of liability.

(3) By what process can householders residing in close proximity to the Lucas Heights Atomic Research Establishment, NSW, indemnify themselves against the possibility of incurring losses sustained as a result of a mishap at that establishment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand from inquiries made of the insurance industry by my officers that it has been established practice for many years for property and liability policies issued by insurance companies in Australia to provide for a number of general exclusions which exclude cover, inter alia, in respect of risks as a consequence of war, invasion, acts of foreign enemies, hostilities (whether war be declared or not) and any loss attributable to nuclear weapons material, nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from nuclear fuel. While an insured person could not claim under his insurance policy in respect of nuclear damage that falls within an exclusion clause, it could be open to such a person to claim compensation under common law from the person or persons responsible for the damage sustained.

(2) The attitude of the Commonwealth with regard to acceptance of liability would depend largely on whether the Commonwealth itself was responsible for the damage sustained. As indicated in part (2) of my answer to House of Representatives Question No. 3676 (Hansard) of 18 August 1982, page 650), whether the Commonwealth would be liable to meet any loss resulting from nuclear damage would depend on the facts of each particular case. Broadly, where the Commonwealth uses radioactive materials or is directly responsible for their use , any Commonwealth liability would depend on general principles of liability that would apply equally to private persons or corporations.

(3) It is my understanding that insurance is not available from the insurance industry in Australia to cover householders against any loss sustained as a result of a mishap at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission establishment at Lucas Heights and that it would be a matter for a householder to claim compensation at common law. The Commonwealth would, of course, stand by the Commission to ensure its ability to meet any damages awarded against it. However , the Commission maintains the highest standards of safety of its nuclear facilities and the Government believes that the possibility of accidents arising out of the Commission's operations at Lucas Heights is highly unlikely. My comments in (2) above are also relevant. As indicated in my answer to Question No. 3676, certain reviews are in process in this area as a result of Commonwealth action and consideration is being given, inter alia, to the adequacy of the protection afforded under common law to persons who sustain loss or damage arising from the use of nuclear material.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the Australian Association of Dieticians which claimed that the Australian public was being fed misleading and often untrue information on nutrition and diet.
(2) Is that statement correct, if so, what is his Department doing to co- ordinate a nutrition education program in the public and private sectors

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) It is my Department's view that the statement is substantially correct. My Department has undertaken nutrition education activities in both the public and private sectors for many years.

A wide range of nutrition education publications is produced by my Department and by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC). These publications provide both a reference for the development of nutrition education and an authoritative source of scientifically based information on food and nutrition for the public. They are widely distributed and include booklets and pamphlets such as Eat Better for Less, Dietary Guidelines for Australians, Nutrition Messages for the Ethnic Community, Welcome to Meals on Wheels, Your Health and Your Figure, Tables of Composition of Australian Foods, Simplified Food Composition Tables and Dietary Allowances for Use in Australia, as well as the poster A Food Guide for Good Health.
Officers of my Department co-operate with industry, including primary producer groups and commodity boards and food manufacturers, in the development of nutrition education programs.

In 1981 my Department sponsored a National Nutrition Education Conference, at the recommendation of the NH and MRC which brought together representatives of the State and Territory health authorities and nutrition and educational bodies. At its Ninety-second Session in October 1981, the NH and MRC acted on one of the Conference recommendations in approving the establishment of a sub-committee of the Council to consider such matters as the co-ordination of nutrition education activities on a national basis. The sub-committee is expected to hold its first meeting later this year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Capacity: Effect of Closure of Foundries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations made by companies which constitute part of the Australian foundry industry that a large number of foundries have been closed as a result of the uncontrolled importation, or dumping, of castings into Australia and that such closure of foundries could severely affect the defence capacity of Australia.

(2) Has he caused any inquiries to be made to (a) examine the relationship between the foundry industry and Australia's defence needs and (b) examine the allegations made concerning the problems of the industry; if so, what inquiries, and what conclusions has he reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A check has been made of records of dumping complaints received by the Department of Industry and Commerce over the last 12 months. In relation to castings there have been three complaints lodged which are identified as possibly falling within this category. They concern railway wheels from Japan and Korea, manhole covers from India and Singapore, malleable cast iron pipe fittings from Japan.

(2) The general capabilities of the foundry industry are monitored on a continuing basis. Foundries which form part of the defence industry base are reviewed at least annually and departmental records of their defence capabilities are adjusted accordingly.

Although the foundry industry is an important element of the defence industry base, defence requirements, especially in time of peace, represent only a small percentage of the industry's total capacity.

Considerable support has been provided to the foundry industry in recent years in relation to defence work and a number of specialised development tasks have been funded, including valves for naval fire extinguishing systems; submarine snorkel and hull valves; large propellor shaft supports and other ferrous items for the RAN FFG class frigates; aluminium bronze propellors for the FFG frigates ; high strength diecastings for sonobuoys.

In summary, although the increased competition and general downturn being experienced by Australian foundries is a matter of concern to the Department of Defence Support, specific recent allegations of dumping do not appear to be directly related to its defence production function. Areas of the industry having special defence significance are closely monitored and are continuing to receive support.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) In a number of cases, yes.

(3) (a) In determining the level of grants to Aboriginal organisations, it is my Department's normal practice to relate salary and wage rates for funded positions to existing awards or to similar positions in the public or private sectors where this is possible. Grants have been increased to cover increases in the salaries and wages paid to employees of Aboriginal organisations.

(b) Permanency and other conditions of employment are matters for consideration by individual Aboriginal organisations. As a general principle, only contributions to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme may be funded by the Commonwealth. Community-based Aboriginal organisations do not come within the definition of an 'approved authority' under the Superannuation Act 1976 and their employees are therefore not eligible to contribute to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. It is a matter for consideration by individual organisations whether they negotiate superannuation packages for their employees .
